revised_title: Ungulate Reproductive Strategies and Feeding Ecology
tldr: This study examines the relationship between feeding ecology, social organization, and life-history variation in ungulates while controlling for the effects of body mass. The research finds that ungulates can be divided along a slow-fast continuum, with browsers having larger litters and smaller neonates than grazers. The study also reveals a strong pattern of covariation between reproductive traits, such as litter size, gestation length, neonate mass, and growth rate, after accounting for the effects of maternal body mass and common ancestry.
